revision.text:
The '''2009 Perak constitutional crisis''' was a political dispute in [[Malaysia]] regarding the legitimacy of the [[Perak]] state government formed in February 2009. It began when three [[Pakatan Rakyat]] state legislators defected, causing a collapse of the state government. The [[Azlan Shah of Perak|Sultan of Perak]] then refused [[List of Menteris Besar of Perak|Menteri Besar]] [[Mohammad Nizar Jamaluddin]]'s request to dissolve the [[Perak State Legislative Assembly|state assembly]] and call for new elections. Instead, [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN), with support from the three defecting assemblymen, formed the new state government.
The BN state government's legitimacy and the Sultan's decision not to dissolve the state assembly was disputed vehemently by Pakatan Rakyat politicians. A series of battles in the courts ensued between Nizar and the new [[Chief Ministers in Malaysia|Menteri Besar]] (Chief Minister), [[Zambry Abdul Kadir]]. Ultimately, the [[Federal Court of Malaysia|Federal Court]] confirmed in February 2010 that Zambry was the lawful menteri besar.
==Overview==
The crisis in Perak began with the announcement by Barisan Nasional's [[Nasarudin Hashim]] of his desire to [[cross the floor]] to [[Pakatan Rakyat]]. This was then followed by the re-defection of Nasaruddin to Barisan Nasional, and the declaration by three Pakatan Rakyat representatives, Deputy Speaker [[Hee Yit Foong]], senior state Executive Council member [[Jamaluddin Mohd. Radzi]] and [[Osman Jailu]], of their intentions to sit as [[Independent (politician)|independents]] while supporting the Barisan Nasional in confidence matters. The Sultan granted an audience to the Prime Minister (who is the head of Perak Barisan Nasional); at this meeting the PM claimed that the Barisan Nasional had the support of the majority of peoples elected representatives in the State Assembly. The Sultan ordered the PM to prove he had a majority. The PM left and returned later (the same day) with 31 elected members of the State Assembly all of whom told the sultan that they had no confidence in the [[Pakatan Rakyat]] and that they would support a Barisan Nasional government. Prior to the defections, Pakatan Rakyat had 32 representatives while Barisan Nasional had 27 representatives. The defections meant that the state now has 28 Pakatan Rakyat representatives, 28 Barisan Nasional representatives, and 3 independent representatives who pledged confidence to Barisan Nasional.
The morality of crossing the floor, the Sultan's power to dismiss the Menteri Besar (First Minister), the validity of pre-signed undated resignation letters, the powers of the Speaker of the House and power of the Election Commission were major issues of this constitutional crisis. On 11 May 2009, the [[Dato' Seri Ir Hj. Mohammad Nizar Bin Jamaluddin v. Dato' Dr. Zambry Bin Abd. Kadir|Kuala Lumpur High Court ruled]] that the Sultan was not constitutionally permitted to dismiss the Menteri Besar, and that Nizar had always been the rightful head of the state government. On 22 May 2009, the Court of Appeal overturned the High Court decision, and confirmed that the Barisan Nasional which has sworn in a new chief minister and parliamentary speaker for Perak should remain in power.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} Furthermore, the Court of Appeal found the trial judge to have erred in confusing the issue of whether the government has lost the confidence of the majority of the house with the issue of whether the Sultan has the power to dismiss the government. However Zambry's position as Menteri Besar will not go unchallenged despite the ruling as Pakatan Rakyat leaders have indicated they intend to file an appeal.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}
==Defections==
The crisis<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205203428/Article/index_html |title=PERAK IN CRISIS: Nizar joins Ningkan as the defiant ones |author=NST Newsdesk |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206143741/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205203428/Article/index_html |archivedate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> began on 25 January 2009 when a member of the Barisan Nasional coalition's main component party - [[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]], [[Nasarudin Hashim]] announced his decision to leave the party and join [[Parti Keadilan Rakyat|PKR]].<ref name="The Star Malaysia">{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/5/nation/3197541&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206102254/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F5%2Fnation%2F3197541&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2009 |title=How the Perak state government fell |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> [[Pakatan Rakyat]] leader, [[Anwar Ibrahim]] made continued claims of the possibility of more [[Dewan Undangan Negeri Perak|Perak]] and also [[Dewan Rakyat|Federal]] lawmakers from [[Barisan Nasional]] [[cross the floor|crossing the floor]] to Pakatan Rakyat. [[Mohammad Nizar Jamaluddin]], the state's [[Menteri Besar|First Minister]], also hinted at the possibility of another three state lawmakers from [[Barisan Nasional]] defecting over to [[Pakatan Rakyat]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/1/26/nation/20090126164646&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203113242/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F1%2F26%2Fnation%2F20090126164646&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 February 2009 |title=Anwar claims more BN reps to defect (updated) |author1=EDWARD RAJENDRA |author2=IVAN LOH |date=26 January 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> Nasarudin Hashim's defection angered the then Prime Minister [[Abdullah Ahmad Badawi]], who chided Nasarudin for being weak and claimed that Nasarudin's defection was because Nasarudin was disappointed in not being offered any senior party posts.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/National/2465994/Article/index_html |title=Abdullah: Don't sulk if not given party post |date=30 January 2009 |author=M. Husairy Othman |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202080014/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/National/2465994/Article/index_html |archivedate=2 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Nasarudin rebutted the Prime Minister's statement and claimed his decision was due to the mood of his constituents.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/1/31/nation/20090131174133&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202173232/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F1%2F31%2Fnation%2F20090131174133&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 February 2009 |title=Nasarudin: I still have the fighting spirit |author=CLARA CHOOI |date=31 January 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> On 29 January 2009 then [[Minister of Finance (Malaysia)|Finance Minister]] [[Najib Razak]] took over from [[Mohammad Tajol Rosli Ghazali]] as the [[Perak]] [[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]] chief, as Tajol Rosli resigned over Nasaruddin's party shift.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/1/30/nation/3157105&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131215558/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F1%2F30%2Fnation%2F3157105&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 January 2009 |title=Najib takes over as Perak chairman |date=30 January 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref>
On 30 January 2009 two state assemblymen from PKR, senior state exco member and one time candidate for First Minister<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Lim Kit Siang |url=http://blog.limkitsiang.com/2008/03/12/no-dap-cec-mandate-for-pas-menteri-besar-in-perak/ |title=No DAP CEC mandate for Pas Menteri Besar in Perak |date=12 March 2008 |accessdate=11 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iprD45FS?url=http://blog.limkitsiang.com/2008/03/12/no-dap-cec-mandate-for-pas-menteri-besar-in-perak/ |archivedate=6 August 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Jamaluddin Mat Radzi]] and [[Mohd Osman Jailu]], who were both previously accused of corruption<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Malaysian Insider |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/18009-court-orders-arrest-of-absent-osman |title=Court orders arrest of absent Osman |date=10 February 2009 |accessdate=11 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iprDu70f?url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/18009-court-orders-arrest-of-absent-osman |archivedate=6 August 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> went missing from their homes.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/1/nation/3172334&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202173358/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F1%2Fnation%2F3172334&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 February 2009 |title=Perak PKR says two state exco men cannot be located |date=1 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> The State Assembly speaker [[V. Sivakumar]] of the [[Democratic Action Party (Malaysia)|DAP]] then declared the seats held by Jamaluddin and Osman vacant and informed the [[Election Commission of Malaysia|Election Commission]] to initiate a [[by-election]] in the two ridings. On 2 February 2009 both assemblymen reappeared and declared themselves independent assemblymen while pledging support for Barisan Nasional in confidence matters.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/3/nation/20090203184845&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205182051/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F3%2Fnation%2F20090203184845&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 February 2009 |title=Behrang rep Jamaluddin quits PKR |author=Saodah Elias |date=3 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> The Election Commission then decided to not heed the speaker's requests and states that no by-elections would be held for the seats held by Jamaluddin and Osman.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/3/nation/20090203130356&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206034753/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F3%2Fnation%2F20090203130356&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2009 |title=EC: No by-election (Update 3) |date=3 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref>
The deputy speaker of the state assembly from the DAP [[Hee Yit Foong]] declared herself independent on 3 February 2009 with the same terms as Jamaluddin and Osman - supporting Barisan Nasional in matters of confidence. Nizar had an audience with the [[Sultan of Perak]] [[Sultan Azlan Shah]] and requested a dissolution of the state assembly to pave way for a [[snap election]] on 4 January 2009.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/5/nation/3200276&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206102320/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F5%2Fnation%2F3200276&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2009 |title=Nizar leaves fate of govt in Sultan’s hands |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> Najib in his capacity as Perak UMNO chief had an audience with Sultan Azlan Shah together with Hee, Jamaluddin and Osman. The latest Pakatan Rakyat lawmaker Nasaruddin announced his return to UMNO citing that "[He] want[s] stability in Perak."<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/5/nation/3200221&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206213207/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F5%2Fnation%2F3200221&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2009 |title=I want to see stability in Perak, says Nasarudin |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> Najib, then sought royal consent for Barisan Nasional to form the new government.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/5/nation/20090205125248&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206102203/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F5%2Fnation%2F20090205125248&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2009 |title=Najib informs Sultan BN can form govt |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref>
An almost similar scenario occurred in the state of [[Sabah]] following the [[Sabah state election, 1994|1994 state election]] whereby [[Parti Bersatu Sabah]] (PBS) won 25 seats against 23 won by Barisan Nasional. Defections by representatives of PBS into Barisan Nasional gave the latter the requisite majority to form government in Sabah.<ref>{{citation|publisher=The Nut Graph|title=When defections felled Sabah|date=6 February 2009|author=Yasmin Masidi|url=http://www.thenutgraph.com/when-defections-felled-sabah|accessdate=4 December 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100113124217/http://thenutgraph.com/when-defections-felled-sabah| archivedate= 13 January 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==New state government==
The Sultan Azlan Shah announced his decision to refuse Nizar's request for a dissolution of the state assembly and asked Nizar and his cabinet to resign, citing his discretion under Article XVIII (2)(b) of the [[Perak State Constitution]]<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205181455/Article/index_html |title=PERAK IN CRISIS: How the Perak palace worded the PR State Government's dismissal |author=Bernama |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206061012/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205181455/Article/index_html |archivedate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/Frontpage/20090205103406/Article/index_html |title=PERAK IN CRISIS: Sultan tells Nizar, Exco to resign |author=NST Newsdesk |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206054909/http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/Frontpage/20090205103406/Article/index_html |archivedate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> after being satisfied that Nizar no longer commanded the support of the majority in the house of assembly.<ref name="The Star Malaysia"/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/5/nation/20090205093949&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206102156/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F5%2Fnation%2F20090205093949&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2009 |title=Perak drama: PM leaves at Istana |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> DAP advisor, [[Lim Kit Siang]], charged that the sultan was obliged to act on the advice of the Menteri Besar and call fresh elections, citing Article 16(6) of the [[Perak State Constitution]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205195545/Article/index_html |title=PERAK IN CRISIS: PR must continue as state government unless BN gets no-confidence vote: Kit |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206143858/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205195545/Article/index_html |archivedate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
Nizar refused to resign and asked the sultan to reconsider and dissolve the assembly, citing reasons of democracy, with backing from leaders of Pakatan Rakyat.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/Frontpage/20090205103406/Article/index_html |title=PERAK IN CRISIS: PR not rejecting Sultan's orders, merely pleading for dissolution of state assembly |author=David Yeow |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206054909/http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/Frontpage/20090205103406/Article/index_html |archivedate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The police cordoned off the state secretariat building and demanded Nizar's cabinet to vacate the building.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/5/nation/20090205185054&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206153844/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F5%2Fnation%2F20090205185054&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2009 |title=Perak: Police take over state building |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> Later in the evening, the sultan asked [[Zambry Abdul Kadir]] to form the next government, removed Nizar from the office of Menteri Besar and swore in Zambry as the new First Minister on 6 February 2009.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Thursday/Frontpage/20090205172202/Article/index_html |title=Zambry Kadir to be sworn in as new Perak MB tomorrow, says PM; PR defying Sultan's ruling, insists on dissolution or no-confidence vote |author=NST Newsdesk |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217224731/http://www.nst.com.my/Thursday/Frontpage/20090205172202/Article/index_html |archivedate=17 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
On the morning of 6 February 2009, Nizar and his exco members returned to the Menteri Besar's office to find that their offices had been cleared. Nizar held a press conference in the office premises along with his exco, but they were promptly ordered to leave by the state secretary<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/NewsBreak/20090206175104/Article/index_html |title=Mohamad Nizar escorted out of Menteri Besar’s office |author=Bernama |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207061534/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/NewsBreak/20090206175104/Article/index_html |archivedate=7 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> on grounds that they had breached an earlier agreement to only take his personal belongings. Nizar was escorted out of the office by the police 45 minutes later.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/Frontpage/20090206192749/Article/index_html |title=Nizar was allowed in MB’s office to take personal belongings only, says state secretary |author=Bernama |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207234458/http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/Frontpage/20090206192749/Article/index_html |archivedate=7 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Some members of the Bar Council defended the sultan's decision saying that His Majesty had acted within the state constitutional provisions<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/National/2472481/Article/index_html |title=Nizar has no choice but to resign, says Bar Council head |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207013947/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/National/2472481/Article/index_html |archivedate=7 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/6/nation/3206266&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207033145/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F6%2Fnation%2F3206266&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 February 2009 |title=Bar: Don’t challenge Sultan’s decision |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> while [[Malaysian Information Ministry|Information Minister]] [[Ahmad Shabery Cheek]] claimed that Nizar's refusal to resign was act of treason.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205210716/Article/index_html |title=PERAK IN CRISIS: Nizar's refusal to step down an 'act of treason': Shabery Cheek |date=5 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206143903/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20090205210716/Article/index_html |archivedate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
Zambry was sworn in as the new Menteri Besar of Perak at 4.08pm that day. The ceremony was attended by members of the Barisan Nasional, including Najib, who arrived in the royal palace, [[Istana Iskandariah]], [[Kuala Kangsar]] under heavy security. Supporters of the Pakatan Rakyat amassed in large number outside the palace to protest the swearing in of Zambry.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[Malay Mail]]|url=http://www.mmail.com.my/Showdown_expected_in_Royal_town.aspx|title=Showdown expected in Royal town|author1=Yushaimi Yahaya |author2=Frankie D'Cruz |author3=Zainal Epi |author4=Kharleez Zubin |author5=Francis C. Nantha |date=6 February 2009|accessdate=6 February 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090207050751/http://mmail.com.my/Showdown_expected_in_Royal_town.aspx| archivedate= 7 February 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/Frontpage/20090206110317/Article/index_html |title=Zambry is new Perak MB |author=NST Newsdesk |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207014142/http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Friday/Frontpage/20090206110317/Article/index_html |archivedate=7 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Anwar Ibrahim challenged the legitimacy of Zambry's appointment by stating that Nizar still remains the Menteri Besar, as guaranteed by the state constitutional provisions, while Nizar continued his call for a motion of no confidence to be held in the assembly sitting before he steps down.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/6/nation/20090206170512&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207033139/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F6%2Fnation%2F20090206170512&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 February 2009 |title=Nizar refuses to step down as Perak MB (Updated) |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> Nizar called for the resignation of Zambry and stated his desire to file an application at the High Court and declare his appointment as unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/6/nation/20090206100717&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207033721/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F6%2Fnation%2F20090206100717&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 February 2009 |title=Perak Update: Nizar wants Dr Zambry removed |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> Nizar and other members of the Pakatan administration returned to the Menteri Besar official residence on 7 February and went ahead with approving three new policies in Perak.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[New Straits Times]] |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Saturday/Frontpage/20090207135438/Article/index_html |title=Nizar holds Exco meeting, approves three new policies |author=NST Newsdesk |date=7 February 2009 |accessdate=7 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208104726/http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Saturday/Frontpage/20090207135438/Article/index_html |archivedate=8 February 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
==Litigation==
DAP chairman and [[Bukit Gelugor]] MP [[Karpal Singh]] issued a notice that he will file a lawsuit against the sultan and the new Barisan Nasional state government for acting beyond the state Constitution. Since the Election Commission had ruled that there was doubt over the vacancy of the state seats of Changkat Jering and Behrang (held by Osman Jailu and Jamaluddin Mohd Radzi respectively) after the pre-signed letters submitted by Assembly Speaker V. Sivakumar in relation to their resignation were contradicted by denials from both assemblymen, it triggered the provision of Article 33 (1). The provision stated that "if any question arises whether a member of the state Legislative Assembly has become disqualified for membership, the decision of the assembly shall be taken and shall be final".<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Sun2Surf|url=http://www.thesundaily.com/article.cfm?id=29893|title=Karpal to file law suit against Perak Sultan|date=6 February 2009|accessdate=6 February 2009}}</ref> Mohammad Nizar Jamaluddin also filed an application at the High Court to declare the swearing in of Zambry Abdul Kadir as unconstitutional and illegal.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Star Online |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/2/6/nation/20090206211134&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207113318/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F2%2F6%2Fnation%2F20090206211134&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 February 2009 |title=Nizar: Dr Zambry’s appointment is illegal |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |df= }}</ref>
== Assembly below a tree ==
=== Before the sitting ===
According to Nizar's senior exco member [[Ngeh Koo Ham]], the Perak state legal advisor, [[Ahmad Kamal Mohd Shahid]] was trying to block state representatives from being notified of an emergency sitting of the state assembly on 3 March. He mentioned that this obstruction was in “contempt of the house” and liable for punishment under house rules.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Malaysian Insider|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/19329-perak-state-legal-advisor-blocks-notification-of-emergency-sitting|title=Perak state legal advisor blocks notification of emergency sitting|date=27 February 2009|accessdate=27 February 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302040548/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/19329-perak-state-legal-advisor-blocks-notification-of-emergency-sitting|archivedate=2 March 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===The sitting===
Because the assemblypersons were barred from entering the building, Sivakumar declared the parking lot of the State Secretariat building as the meeting place. The assembly met under a tree in the parking lot, which would later be known as the [[Democracy tree]]. All the three motions were debated and passed unanimously, 27-0.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Nut Graph| url=http://thenutgraph.com/perak-crisis-deepens |title=Perak crisis deepens|date=3 March 2009 |accessdate=3 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090306210712/http://www.thenutgraph.com/perak-crisis-deepens| archivedate= 6 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
=== 1BLACKMalaysia protest and arrests=== The Coalition for Free and Fair Elections (Bersih) urged Malaysians to wear black on 7 May, to protest the "ongoing Perak coup" by the Barisan Nasional government. "It will be a peaceful but powerful message of civil disobedience: that we, the people, are the politicians' bosses and no politician defiant of public opinion can escape punishment at the next poll," said Bersih representative [[Wong Chin Huat]] at the launch of the 1BLACKMalaysia campaign on 5 May.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenutgraph.com/1blackmalaysia-campaign-for-perak|title=1BLACKMalaysia campaign for Perak |publisher=The Nut Graph | date= 5 May 2009|accessdate=7 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090509074353/http://www.thenutgraph.com/1blackmalaysia-campaign-for-perak| archivedate= 9 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> That evening, Wong was arrested for sedition for writing several articles, including on the 1BLACKMalaysia campaign.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenutgraph.com/wong-chin-huat-arrested-for-sedition |title=1BLACKMalaysia campaign for Perak |publisher=The Nut Graph | date= 5 May 2009|accessdate=7 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090507190441/http://thenutgraph.com/wong-chin-huat-arrested-for-sedition| archivedate= 7 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Security was tight around the state secretariat building where the state assembly is housed. The police cordoned off the roads in the areas from the night before the sitting on 7 May. The police warned political party supporters not to create tension by dressing in black and gathering illegally in protest of the Perak state assembly sitting.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenutgraph.com/dont-wear-black-tomorrow-igp |title=Don't wear black tomorrow, warns IGP |publisher=The Nut Graph | date= 6 May 2009|accessdate=7 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090509103959/http://www.thenutgraph.com/dont-wear-black-tomorrow-igp| archivedate= 9 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> That didn't stop the supporters from showing up, dressed in black. Even before the sitting began, the police had arrested at dozens of people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenutgraph.com/perak-assembly-sitting |title=Impasse in Perak assembly after BN tries to wrest control |publisher=The Nut Graph | date= 7 May 2009|accessdate=7 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090508022552/http://www.thenutgraph.com/perak-assembly-sitting| archivedate= 8 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8037323.stm |title=Dozens held at Malaysian protest |publisher=BBC News | date= 7 May 2009|accessdate=7 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090508121118/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8037323.stm| archivedate= 8 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==High Court rules takeover illegal==
{{Main|Dato' Seri Ir Hj. Mohammad Nizar Bin Jamaluddin v. Dato' Dr. Zambry Bin Abd. Kadir}}
On 11 May 2009, the [[High Courts of Malaysia|High Court]] of [[Kuala Lumpur]] ruled that, since there had been no [[vote of no confidence]] in the state assembly, the Barisan Nasional takeover was "illegal" and the Pakatan Rakyat's Mohd Nizar Jamaluddin still held office.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSKLR437912 |work=Reuters |title=Malaysia court rules opposition runs Perak state |first=David |last=Chance |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=11 May 2009 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515005134/https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSKLR437912 |archivedate=15 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> The opposition is expected to call for fresh elections, while the ruling party has vowed to appeal.<ref name="reuters"/> The Regent of Perak [[Raja Nazrin Shah]] has agreed to see Datuk Seri Nizar Jamaluddin on his request for dissolution of the Perak state legislature and the call for a fresh election.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/26145-raja-nazrin-agrees-to-meet-nizar |title=Raja Nazrin agrees to meet Nizar |publisher=Malaysian Insider |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=11 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iprAeqlD?url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/26145-raja-nazrin-agrees-to-meet-nizar |archivedate=6 August 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
The night of 11 May, the Pakatan Rakyat Perak executive council met and dismissed the state secretary and state legal adviser. Nizar announced his executive council would report for work the next day, and asserted that the 7 May sitting of the state assembly was invalid because it had been called by Zambry. By implication, this would prevent the Barisan-appointed Speaker from convening a new sitting of the state assembly.<ref>{{cite news|first=Shannon |last=Teoh |title=Perak MB suspends state secretary, legal advisor |date=12 May 2009 |publisher= |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/26161-nizar-suspends-state-secretary-legal-advisor- |work=The Malaysian Insider |pages= |accessdate=12 May 2009 |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090512162948/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/26161-nizar-suspends-state-secretary-legal-advisor- |archivedate=12 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On 12 May, Zambry filed his appeal at the Court of Appeal, which granted him a [[stay of execution]] on the court ruling, allowing him to retain the post of Menteri Besar until his appeal is heard.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/12/nation/20090512080820&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515100359/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F5%2F12%2Fnation%2F20090512080820&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 May 2009 |title=Perak crisis: Stay of execution granted; Zambry to resume duties |publisher=TheStar Online |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=12 May 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/SE%2BAsia/Story/STIStory_376113.html |title=Court lets BN reclaim post |publisher=The Straits Times |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517012911/http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/SE%2BAsia/Story/STIStory_376113.html |archivedate=17 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Overturning of the High Court verdict== The Court of Appeal overturned the High Court decision and held that Zambry the lawful Menteri Besar. The Court of Appeal's verdict was upheld by the Federal Court with a 5-0 verdict in February 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2010/2/10/nation/5649677&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212080647/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2010%2F2%2F10%2Fnation%2F5649677&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 February 2010 |title=5-0 for BN’s Zambry |date=10 February 2010 |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |accessdate=4 February 2011 |df= }}</ref>
The constitutional crisis came to an indefinite end with Pakatan leaders having no choice but to obey the ruling. As a result, no fresh election was called and Zambry continues as Menteri Besar while Nizar became the opposition leader.
== Comments and interpretations of the constitutional crisis ==
On 2 March 2009, the president of the Malaysian Bar Council, [[Ambiga Sreenevasan]] remarked that the Institution of the Perak and its constitution are breaking down.<ref name="Ambiga"/> She also mentioned that the secretary of state does not have the power to interfere in the affair of the assembly nor does the police, while the speaker has the very rights within the constitution to exercise his power to call for an emergency sitting of the state assembly.<ref name="Ambiga">{{cite news |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/19501-institutions-breaking-down-says-bar-council |title=Institutions breaking down, says Bar Council |publisher=The Malaysian Insider |date=2 March 2009 |accessdate=2 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090303124553/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/19501-institutions-breaking-down-says-bar-council| archivedate= 3 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> She was also quoted saying “Our institutions, that is the courts, the police, et cetera, are being tested and we can judge for ourselves whether they are acting independently or not.”<ref name="Ambiga"/>
[[Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah]], an UMNO politician veteran agreed with Pakatan MB to dissolve the state legislative and call for fresh state elections to resolve the political stalemate in Perak.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/12/nation/20090512110624&sec=nation |title=Dissolve state assembly, Ku Li urges Sultan |publisher=TheStar Online |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=12 May 2009 |author=SYED AZHAR |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ips5N73p?url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F5%2F12%2Fnation%2F20090512110624&sec=nation |archivedate=6 August 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
The Human Rights Commission (Suhakam) has joined the ever increasing chorus calling for fresh state elections to resolve the political stalemate in Perak.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suhakam calls for state election - Malaysiakini |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/104149 |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iprEOHWa?url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/104149 |archivedate=6 August 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=1 August 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Hardial Singh Khaira, a legal researcher, has done a full research on ''The Dismissal and Appointment of Menteri Besars in Perak'' before any judgment was delivered on the Perak constitutional crisis by any Malaysian court and the full article can be viewed online.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Perak Constitutional Crisis |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/15226898/The-Perak-Constitutional-Crisis |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ipsAOZAz?url=http://www.scribd.com/doc/15226898/The-Perak-Constitutional-Crisis |archivedate=6 August 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=1 August 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>

The '''2011 crackdown on dissidents in China''' refers to the arrest of dozens of mainland Chinese rights lawyers, activists and grassroots agitators in a response to the [[2011 Chinese pro-democracy protests]].<ref name="wpost20110403"/><ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb" /><ref>{{cite news|author=Tania Branigan in Beijing |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/31/china-crackdown-on-activists-arrests-disappearances |title=Crackdown in China spreads terror among dissidents | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= 31 March 2011|accessdate=2011-04-23 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110406223826/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/31/china-crackdown-on-activists-arrests-disappearances| archivedate= 6 April 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Eimer |first=David |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8447908/China-arrests-dissident-as-crackdown-continues.html |title=China arrests dissident as crackdown continues |publisher=Telegraph |date=2011-04-13 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110426072629/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8447908/China-arrests-dissident-as-crackdown-continues.html| archivedate= 26 April 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Sui-Lee Wee |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/15/us-china-dissent-idUSTRE73E1HB20110415 |title=China detains rights lawyer, sends man to labor camp |publisher=Reuters |date= 15 April 2011|accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref> Since the protests, at least 54 Chinese activists have been arrested or detained by authorities in the biggest crackdown on dissent since the [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989]].<ref>https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5je3ZgbedCbix0LQxKZVpiHivajsg?docId=CNG.a3f8092c66918f0cedb929502b657e94.421</ref><ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/16/world/asia/16briefs-ART-china.html | work=The New York Times | first=Edward | last=Wong | title=China: 54 Detained in Crackdown | date=15 April 2011}}</ref> Since the start of the protests in mid-February 2011, [[Human rights in China|human rights groups]] have claimed that more than 54 people have been arrested by authorities, some of whom have been charged with crimes. Among those arrested are bloggers who criticise the government such as [[Ai Weiwei]], lawyers who pursue cases against the government, and human rights activists.
== Arrests == At least 54 leading activists have been arrested or detained by authorities including:<ref name="nytimes1"/>
# [[Ai Weiwei]] ({{zh|艾未未}}), prominent dissident, had expressed his sympathy with the [[2011 Chinese pro-democracy protests]]: Amid Boxun's online campaign, Ai had posted on his Twitter account on 24 February: "I didn’t care about jasmine at first, but people who are scared by jasmine sent out information about how harmful jasmine is often, which makes me realize that jasmine is what scares them the most. What a jasmine!"<ref name=wpost20110403 /><ref>Twitter (8 April 2011).https://twitter.com/aiww/status/40606428100177920</ref> Ai's studio was raided by police, who took away computer equipment; a number of his entourage were also arrested by police.<ref name="guardian">{{Cite news |first=Tania | last=Branigan | pages= | title=Ai Weiwei's detention in China causes growing global concern | date=5 April 2011 | work=The Guardian | url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/apr/05/eu-us-china-ai-weiwei | accessdate=19 April 2011 | location=London}}</ref> He was arrested on 3 April.<ref name="wpost20110403">{{Cite news|first=Keith B. |last=Richburg |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/chinese-artist-ai-wei-wei-arrested-in-latest-government-crackdown/2011/04/03/AFHB5PVC_story.html |title=Chinese artist Ai Weiwei arrested in latest government crackdown |work=The Washington Post |date=3 April 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1MA1PEC?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/chinese-artist-ai-wei-wei-arrested-in-latest-government-crackdown/2011/04/03/AFHB5PVC_story.html |archivedate=17 April 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on 7 April that Ai was under investigation for 'economic crimes'.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Chinese artist Ai Weiwei held for 'economic crimes' | date = 7 April 2011 | publisher=BBC | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12994785 }}</ref><ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="guardian_2011-04-15">{{Cite news|first=Tania |last=Branigan |pages= |title=Ai Weiwei arrest: Chinese lawyer and designer are latest to disappear |date=15 April 2011 |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/15/ai-weiwei-lawyer-designer-disappear |accessdate=20 April 2011 |deadurl=no |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110419000943/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/apr/15/ai-weiwei-lawyer-designer-disappear |archivedate=19 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> On 20 April Ai was appointed Visiting Professor of the University of the Arts in Berlin.<ref name="reuters_2011-04-20">{{Cite news | title = Detained artist Ai offered Berlin university post | date = 20 April 2011 | publisher= | agency=Reuters | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/20/us-germany-china-dissident-idUSTRE73J3VH20110420 }}</ref> # [[Chen Wei (dissident)|Chen Wei]] (陈卫), 42, a leading human rights activist in central Sichuan province, on the morning of 20 February was charged with "subversion of state power" and "inciting subversion of state power".<ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb">{{Cite news |first=David |last=Pierson |pages= |language= |title=Online call for protests in China prompts crackdown |date=26 February 2011 |work=Los Angeles Times |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-china-crackdown-20110227,0,4764714.story?track=rss |accessdate=26 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wnIe28Bl?url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-china-crackdown-20110227,0,4764714.story?track=rss |archivedate=26 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="cnn_2011-04-13" /><ref name="reuters" /> Chen Wei was sentenced in late December to nine years in prison.<ref name=Gu01/> # [[Chen Xi (dissident)|Chen Xi]], 57, (no relation to Chen Wei) was sentenced in late December to ten years in prison in [[Guiyang]], [[Guizhou]], on charges linked essays he published online and after he campaigned for independent candidates to win seats in elections to the [[National People's Congress#Membership|local People's Congress]].<ref name=Gu01>Hennock, Mary, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/26/china-jails-dissident-chen-xi?newsfeed=true "China jails dissident Chen Xi for 10 years"], ''The Guardian'', 26 December 2011 04.23 EST. Retrieved 2011-12-26.</ref> # Cheng Li (成力), performing artist.<ref name="guardian" /> # [[Ding Mao]] (丁矛), an activist, was arrested between 25 March and 28 March.<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="cnn_2011-04-13" /><ref name="reuters" /> # Dong Jiqing, husband of housing rights lawyer [[Ni Yulan]]<ref name="nytimes1"/> # Gu Chuan, critical writer;<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /> # Guo Gai (郭盖), performing artist;<ref name="guardian" /> # [[Guo Weidong]] (郭卫东), a businessman and blogger, was charged with "inciting subversion".<ref name="reuters" /><ref>{{cite web|last=France |first=Agence |url=http://news.malaysia.msn.com/regional/article.aspx?cp-documentid=4707907 |title=China arrests more activists for urging protests - Latest news around the world and developments close to home - MSN Malaysia News |publisher=News.malaysia.msn.com |date=2011-03-13 |accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref> # Hu Mingfeng, accountant of Ai Weiwei;<ref name="guardian_2011-04-15" /> # [[Hua Chunhui]] (华春辉), sent to [[Re-education through labor|Re-education through Labor]];<ref name="reuters" /><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Agence France-Presse]] – 12 April 2011 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g4nKelbFrJLXxRwSgHddRh8dScuQ?docId=CNG.339fc2df9b43da9680cd9933ecbd37aa.4d1 |title=AFP: 'Jasmine' activists in China labour camps: group |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-04-12 |accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref> # Huang Xiang (黄香), performing artist;<ref name="guardian" /> # [[Jiang Tianyong]] (江天勇), a [[human rights]] activist and lawyer, was detained by police on 19 February 2011, when he was grabbed and thrown into a waiting van. On 20 February, police in Beijing went to the home of Jiang Tianyong’s brother, where Jiang was temporarily staying, and confiscated his laptop computer. On 21 February they returned and searched Jiang’s room, confiscating a desktop computer and other items. Jiang was released on 19 April 2011. Jiang earlier was tortured in prison.<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="reuters" /><ref name="canadian">{{cite news |first=Gillian | last=Wong | pages= | title=China releases prominent rights lawyer who disappeared in crackdown | date=20 April 2011 | publisher=The Canadian | agency=Associated Press | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5hB0QTz8Reat_mArh9zNeWsEN_F3w?docId=6617357 | accessdate=20 April 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}</ref> # [[Jiao Guobiao]], a crusader activist against the [[Central Propaganda Department]], was detained on 12 September 2012 in Beijing during the run-up to the [[18th National Congress of the Communist Party of China]]. # Jin Mingri, senior pastor of the free church called [[Zion Church (Beijing)|Zion Church]] in Beijing was shortly detained to be prevented from attending Lausanne Conference in South Africa. He is a graduate of Beijing University, Nanjing Seminary, and Fuller Theological Seminary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ppd.cecc.gov/QueryResultsDetail.aspx?PrisonerNum=8195|title=Congressional-Executive Commission on China Political Prisoner Database (PPD)|date=|accessdate=2011-05-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721181357/http://ppd.cecc.gov/QueryResultsDetail.aspx?PrisonerNum=8195|archive-date=21 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/china_705/interview/extended.html|title=PBS Frontline: Jesus in China|date=|accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> # Jin Tianming, senior pastor of the free church called [[Shouwang Church]] in Beijing was shortly detained and later released into house arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/us-renews-concerns-over-china-clampdown-203106918.html |title=US renews concerns over China clampdown - Yahoo! News |publisher=Ca.news.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110417-china-detains-underground-church-followers-group |title=China detains underground church followers: group |publisher=FRANCE 24 |date=2011-04-17 |accessdate=2011-04-23 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> # Lan Jingyuan (兰靖远), arrested and released on bail to await trial;<ref name="ArtMediaAgency" /> # Li Hai (李海), critical writer;<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /> # [[Li Shuangde]] (李双德), is a citizen lawyer and an activist based in Chengdu. He operates a legal aid center in Chengdu, and provides legal aid to citizens who cannot afford to hire a lawyer. He has been harassed on numerous occasions in the past by local officials. He was detained in March 2011, and sentenced in June 2011 to four months in jail on charges of credit card fraud. He was released on 22 July 2011.<ref name="ArtMediaAgency">{{Cite news|first= |last= |pages= |language=French |title=Détentions, condamnations et disparitions en Chine |date=12 April 2011 |work=ArtMediaAgency |url=http://www.artmediaagency.com/7377/detentions-condamnations-et-disparitions-en-chine/ |accessdate=19 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110420010502/http://www.artmediaagency.com/7377/detentions-condamnations-et-disparitions-en-chine/ |archivedate=20 April 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>Human Rights in China, "[http://www.hrichina.org/content/5481 Sichuan Barefoot Lawyer Speaks Out against Trumped-up Charge]," 22 July 2011</ref> # Li Tiantian, human rights lawyer;<ref name="reuters" /> # Li Tie, writer, alleged to be a member of the China Social Democracy Party;<ref name = "NYTLi">[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/20/world/asia/li-tie-prominent-chinese-activist-sentenced-to-jail.html "China Sentences Another Prominent Activist to Prison"] article by Michael Wines in ''[[The New York Times]]'' 19 January 2012</ref> # [[Liang Haiyi]], from Harbin, was arrested after posting information on the 2011 protests on a chat room.<ref name="reuters" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Foster |first=Peter |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8346855/Online-activists-calling-for-Jasmine-revolution-arrested-in-China.html |title=Online activists calling for Jasmine revolution arrested in China |publisher=Telegraph |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110310221726/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8346855/Online-activists-calling-for-Jasmine-revolution-arrested-in-China.html| archivedate= 10 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> # Liu Huiping (刘慧萍), human rights activist;<ref name="reuters">{{Cite news |first= | last= | pages= | language=Spanish | title=China releases prominent rights lawyer who disappeared in crackdown | date=1 April 2011 | publisher=Agencia EFE | work=Reuters | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/epa/article/ALeqM5gAPLGcWlFy2XpULSc2LHVJYkamxQ?docId=1499742 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124172743/http://www.google.com/hostednews/epa/article/ALeqM5gAPLGcWlFy2XpULSc2LHVJYkamxQ?docId=1499742 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=24 January 2013 | accessdate=20 April 2011 }}</ref> # Liu Shihui, human rights lawyer;<ref name="reuters" /> # [[Liu Xianbin]] on 25 March was sentenced to 10 years in prison for "slandering the Communist Party" and subversion.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18530193?story_id=18530193&fsrc=rss |title=Banyan: On the defensive |publisher=The Economist |date=2011-04-07 |accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/04/world/asia/04china.html?src=twrhp | work=The New York Times | first=Andrew | last=Jacobs | title=Ai Weiwei, Dissident Chinese Artist, Is Detained | date=3 April 2011}}</ref> # Liu Xiaoyuan, an activist lawyer, on 15 April was taken away by officers who identified themselves as being from Beijing's public security bureau. They questioned him about cases he had worked on before and which had to do with his friend [[Ai Weiwei]]. Ai had asked Liu to represent him in case he would be taken away. He was released in the evening of 19 April.<ref name="canadian" /> # Liu Zhengang, works for design and architecture company of Ai Weiwei's wife;<ref name="guardian_2011-04-15" /> # Liu Zhengqing, critical writer;<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /> # Ma Liangfu, from Inner Mongolia, was sentenced to re-education through labor.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} # [[Mao Hengfeng]] from Shanghai, who campaigned against a strict one-child policy was taken from her home to a labour camp.<ref>{{cite news|author=Sui-Lee Wee |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/02/24/idINIndia-55131420110224 |title=Chinese dissident sent to labour camp again | Reuters |publisher=In.reuters.com |date= 24 February 2011|accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref> [[File:Voa chinese Ni Yulan 4oct10.jpg|thumb|Ni Yulan, in prison tortured and forced into a wheelchair, left homeless and arrested again in April 2011]] # [[Ni Yulan]] (倪玉兰), a critical lawyer working for victims of land eviction cases, was arrested together with her husband. Only a year prior, she had been released from an earlier detention of two years. Due to torture in prison, she needed a wheelchair. After her release a year ago, she had to live in a tent, since she was a victim of land eviction herself.<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref name="tagesschau" /><ref>Peter Ford, [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-Pacific/2010/0706/Why-Chinese-activist-Ni-Yulan-lost-nearly-everything "Why Chinese activist Ni Yulan lost nearly everything"], Christian Science Monitor, 6 July 2010.</ref> [[File:Ran Yunfei.JPG|thumb|Blogger [[Ran Yunfei]] charged with [[inciting subversion of state power]]]] # Quan Lianzhao (全连昭), activist;<ref name="reuters" /> # [[Ran Yunfei]] (冉云飞), a former leader of the student movement 1989, who has served years in prison, today a well-known blogger and writer from Sichuan, was arrested on charges of "inciting subversion of state power".<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="cnn_2011-04-13" /><ref name="reuters" /><ref>{{cite news|author=Reuters |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/28/china-arrests-blogger-ran-yunfei |title=China arrests blogger Ran Yunfei | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= 28 March 2011|accessdate=2011-04-23 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110419204121/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/28/china-arrests-blogger-ran-yunfei| archivedate= 19 April 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> # Sun Desheng (孙德胜), activist;<ref name="reuters" /> # [[Tang Jingling]] (唐荆陵), Guangzhou-based human rights lawyer.<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="reuters" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/04/11/135305676/china-cracks-down-on-christians-at-outdoor-service |title=China Cracks Down On Christians At Outdoor Service |publisher=NPR |date=2011-04-11 |accessdate=2011-04-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110504215713/http://www.npr.org/2011/04/11/135305676/china-cracks-down-on-christians-at-outdoor-service| archivedate= 4 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> # Tang Jitian, human rights lawyer;<ref name="reuters" /> # [[Teng Biao]] (滕彪), of the [[Open Constitution Initiative]], was reported missing / incommunicado.<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="reuters" /><ref name="AP_27Febplans">{{Cite news|first= |last= |pages= |language= |title=Organizers urge sustained street protests in China |date=23 February 2011 |publisher=[[Mercury News]] |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_17457973?nclick_check=1 |accessdate=26 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wlyrzY1r?url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_17457973?nclick_check=1 |archivedate=26 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="bbcnames">Bbc.co.uk. "[http://www.bbc.co.uk/zhongwen/trad/china/2011/02/110220_brief_china_police.shtml bbc.co.uk]." ''逾百中国维权人士被捕失踪.'' Retrieved on 21 February 2011.</ref> # [[Wei Qiang (dissident)|Wei Qiang]] (魏强) a former art student who has worked at Ai Weiwei's studio, has been sentenced to two years of re-education through labour for attending a pro-democracy protest.<ref>{{cite web|author=14 April 2011 12:00AM |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hard-labour-for-ais-student/story-e6frg6so-1226038714876 |title=Hard labour for Ai's student |publisher=The Australian |date=2011-04-14 |accessdate=2011-04-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110501123506/http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hard-labour-for-ais-student/story-e6frg6so-1226038714876| archivedate= 1 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> # Wen Tao, journalist of Global Times, friend of Ai Weiwei;<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="guardian_2011-04-15" /> # [[Wu Lebao]] (吴乐宝), [[list of Chinese dissidents|Chinese dissident]], friend of Ai Weiwei. Wu was close to Ai before the Chinese Jasmine Revolution happened, and was suspected of leading Chinese Jasmine Revolution with Ai Weiwei. Wu was interrogated and detained over three months;<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/tortured-11162011112747.html|title=Jasmine Activist 'Tortured'|work=[[Radio Free Asia]] |date=2011-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|language=zh| url=http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2011/08/201108230325.shtml | title=蚌埠当局误把吴乐宝当"散花（茉莉花）天女"|work=[[Boxun.com]] |date=2011-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|language=zh| url=http://www.rfa.org/cantonese/news/dissident-02152013095232.html|title=吴乐宝成功抵澳大利亚|work=[[Radio Free Asia]] |date=2013-02-25}}</ref> # Yang Qiuyu (杨秋雨), campaigner for the rights of petitioners, took pictures of a site mentioned in connection with the 'Jasmine Revolution', was seized by police at Xidan in Beijing and without trial was sent to a Labour Camp.<ref name="guardian_2011-04-15" /> # Ye Du, a critical writer, was arrested;<ref name="TorontoStar">{{Cite news | first=Jian | last=Ma | pages= | title=China’s sunflower revolutionary | date=14 April 2011 | publisher=[[TorontoStar]] |agency= |url=https://www.thestar.com/opinion/editorialopinion/article/975047--china-s-sunflower-revolutionary |accessdate=20 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="WeltOnline">{{Cite news | first=Jian | last=Ma | pages= | language=German | title=Im Namen der Kerne | date=19 April 2011 | publisher=[[WeltOnline]] |agency= |url=https://www.welt.de/print/die_welt/debatte/article13211142/Im-Namen-der-Kerne.html |accessdate=20 April 2011}}</ref> # Yu Yunfeng, from Harbin, was sentenced to re-education through labor. # Zhang Jinsong, cousin and driver of Ai Weiei;<ref name="guardian_2011-04-15" /> # [[Zhu Yufu]] (朱虞夫), a longtime activist and a founder of the China Democracy Party, was arrested and accused of "inciting subversion of state power."<ref name="TorontoStar" /><ref name="WeltOnline" /><ref name="cnn_2011-04-13">{{Cite news|first= |last= |pages= |title=China arrests dissident in crackdown, human rights group says |date=13 April 2011 |publisher=CNN |agency= |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-04-13/world/china.dissident.arrests_1_china-arrests-chinese-human-rights-defenders-china-democracy-party?_s=PM:WORLD |accessdate=19 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110422072524/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-04-13/world/china.dissident.arrests_1_china-arrests-chinese-human-rights-defenders-china-democracy-party?_s=PM%3AWORLD |archivedate=22 April 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="reuters" /> # Zhui Hun (追魂), performing artist.<ref name="guardian" /> Renee Xia, the international director of [[Chinese Human Rights Defenders]], commented on 26 February 2011: "The numbers point to a bad situation that is only getting worse. In the matter of a few days, we have seen more cases of prominent lawyers subjected to prolonged disappearances, more criminal charges that may carry lengthy prison sentences for activists, more home raids, and a heavier reliance on extralegal measures.";<ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb" /> In addition, according to Phelim Kine of the Human Right Watch, three people, Lan Ruoyu, Tan Yanhua, and Zhang Haibo, are believed to be still missing by September, 2011. A total of about 17 people from the above list remain in detention, prison, or re-education through labor. An unknown number of people remain held in house detention.
== Supervision and summoning == * Up to 200 people are subject to reinforced supervision or house arrest.<ref name="tagesschau">{{cite web|url=http://tagesschau.vo.llnwd.net/d3/audio/2011/0407/AU-20110407-1518-2501.ogg |title=China warns not to interfere with detention of Ai Weiwei |publisher=Tagesschau |date=7 April 2011 |accessdate=9 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723063056/http://tagesschau.vo.llnwd.net/d3/audio/2011/0407/AU-20110407-1518-2501.ogg |archivedate=23 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> * Since mid February, more than a hundred people have been summoned or questioned by police.<ref name="harshest_crackdown">{{Cite news|first=Tania |last=Branigan |pages= |language= |title=China's jasmine revolution: police but no protesters line streets of Beijing |date=27 February 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=UK |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/27/china-jasmine-revolution-beijing-police |accessdate=27 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wotLedbP?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/27/china-jasmine-revolution-beijing-police |archivedate=27 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> * On the morning of 19 February, National Security officers in Yichang City, Hubei Province arrived at the home of activist Shi Yulin 石玉林, summoning him for questioning. While Shi was being interrogated, officers searched his home, confiscating a computer. Shi recently had taken efforts to support Shandong human rights defender Chen Guangcheng 陈关诚.<ref name="new_century_news">{{Cite news |first= |last= |pages=|title=Hubei Democracy and Human Rights Activist Shi Yulin Summoned by Police, Home Searched 湖北民主维 权人士石玉林被警察传唤抄家 |date=19 February 2011 |work=New Century News |url=http://www.newcenturynews.com/Article/china/201102/20110219143911.html |accessdate=16 April 2011}}</ref>
==Commentary== *The UN Working Group on Enforced or Involuntary Disappearances expressed "serious concern at the recent wave of enforced disappearances".<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 8 April 2011 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hGiEfvJwSOIXSI_n6ahA7GIbhadw?docId=CNG.df8b4b9dbec22272702ca1de92279174.ad1 |title=AFP: UN rights panel raps China over 'disappeared' |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-04-08 |accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref> *According to [[Amnesty International]] more than 100 activists, lawyers and writers have been detained or have simply disappeared—some of them just for using the words "Jasmine Revolution" in a Twitter feed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,755114,00.html |title=Ai Weiwei Under Arrest: Europeans Call for Release of Chinese Artist - SPIEGEL ONLINE - News - International |publisher=Spiegel.de |date= |accessdate=2011-04-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110422201845/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0%2C1518%2C755114%2C00.html |archivedate=22 April 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> * According to [[Chinese Human Rights Defenders]], "this is the harshest crackdown [...] in the past 15 years. Every day, someone is disappeared, taken away, detained or charged."<ref>{{cite web|last=Saiget |first=Robert |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hKPU5BVUP4J49gn97kKb3az1GFtg |title=AFP: Government critics under fire in China crackdown |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-03-30 |accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref>

The '''Alley Dwelling Authority''' was a government funded program that sought to help with the development of [[alley]] dwellings in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington DC]]. Alleys in Washington DC suffered from a variety of problems, most prominently [[Human overpopulation|overpopulation]] and [[poverty]]. During the 1800s in [[Foggy Bottom]], Washington DC’s population changed drastically. Starting in 1822, there was an estimated forty households with a majority of skilled workers; however, by 1860 there were around 175 households. This drastic change yielded the percentage of skilled workers and unskilled workers to fluctuate. This suggests that there was a boom in the economy and a drastic change in the need for [[factory]] hands. This change was beneficial because it created greater numbers to flock into these new areas of Foggy Bottom, then forcing groups like the Alley Dwelling Authorities to step in and reconstruct old dilapidated homes.
== Actions of the ADA ==
The ADA was given the task of evaluating homes and streets to see if they met proper living conditions. Specific documentation would state the reasons why the area needed to be renovated. This documentation would then be sent from the authority to legislation for approval. Individuals in legislation included (but not exclusively) [[Eleanor Roosevelt]]. Common reasons as to why an area needed to be renovated were: excess of individuals in one home, too many [[African Americans]] in and around the area, or a fading exterior. After the ADA gained approval from legislation, it would then give the occupants of the houses anywhere from two to four months to find a new home. By July 1, 1944, all of the houses in Foggy Bottom had been evacuated and plans were set forward for renovation. This act sought to produce larger living spaces for individuals with better conditions, so that the owners could charge more for [[renting|rent]]. Higher rent prices were acceptable at the time because of a boom in available jobs, which created a more competitive [[supply and demand]] market for housing. Monthly rent usually ranged anywhere from seventeen dollars to thirty-seven dollars. These prices fluctuated often because of the available jobs and the condition of the houses. Older houses were typically cheaper than new homes, some of which had running water, [[gas heater]]s and cooling systems. Statistics suggest that, on average, the greater wealth arose from the majority of white residents, but also that black wealth was steadily increasing due to new job patterns.<ref>Borchert, James. Alley Life in Washington: Family, Community, Religion, and Folklife in the City, 1850-1970. Urbana: University of Illinois, 1980. Print.</ref>
== Results of Actions ==
In the process of attempting to improve upon DC living standards, the ADA demolished entire alleys. By tearing down the houses of alley dwellers, the ADA was able to refurbish the area into better houses. Funding for the new houses were from the [[United States Housing Authority]]. The two loans that were made amounted to a total of $6,000,000 and $4,258,000. However, the construction rendered alley dwellers whose houses were being fixed with no place to live. Of the five completed projects, four of them were being occupied by African Americans. The intended purpose for these projects was to lower crime and death rates. Moreover, there was a conflict when the white population did not want the black population to dwell near them. The ADA had several moral and legal conflicts to manage, as it had to undergo multiple legal loopholes to excise the alley dwellers out of their homes.
== Black demographic == The black population in DC Alleys was at its zenith during the late nineteenth century, although they could not afford sufficient housing. The black population needed more housing in order to live comfortably, but since they did not have more housing, living conditions were often cramped, particularly in small [[apartment]]s. At the same time, it was necessary for them to live in DC and be close enough to their jobs. John Ihlder, a supporter of [[public housing]] and an executive officer for the ADA, dealt with implementing alley development. One government official whom Ihlder contacted was Dr. William T. Grady, chairman in office. The two exchanged letters in order to deal with St. Mary’s court apartment which was specifically built for “negro occupancy,”. The white population believed that the black population should be completely moved out of the DC district, and that St. Mary’s court should be renewed and housed for the white people living in these areas. They began to have regulations on being able to live in these apartments, causing “negroes” to live in the [[Rural–urban fringe|outskirts]] of town. The regulations included working in the West End, and preferences toward families instead of single people. Ihlder stated that three-four years before June 25, 1939, African Americans occupied most alley dwellings. five to six thousand African Americans paid low rent housing with the alley dwellings. The whites wanted to and had nuked the blacks “negro occupancy”. The government stated that this was inaccurate, that the reasoning for the blacks being moved out from these alleys was for them to improve the conditions of their living environment. Their plan was to put indoor [[plumbing]] and polish the housing and make more room, and made blacks move into low income home for 3–4 months. When the blacks came back to purchase their homes they were unable to afford it, due to the new improvements. Not all government officials were trying to push blacks out of these alleys; one of the main advocates for blacks staying in these alleys was Eleanor Roosevelt.
== Eleanor Roosevelt's involvement == [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] was a strong advocate for the Washington Housing Authority, as she looked to put an end to discrimination. As the president of the committee Eleanor Roosevelt made it a priority for her to aid the alley dwellers.<ref>"First Lady Biography: Eleanor Roosevelt." The National First Lady Library. The National First Lady Library, n.d. Web. 26 Apr. 2013. <http://www.firstladies.org/biographies/firstladies.aspx?biography=33>.</ref> On June 12, 1934 the District of Columbia Alley Dwelling Act was passed, establishing the Washington Housing Authority as an independent agency. The government attempted to eliminate the alley dwelling lifestyle and tried to improve the situation which was the cause for the [[New Deal]].
== ADA and Snow's Court ==
The ADA had a significant effect upon the development of alleys, particularly in Foggy Bottom. An alley dwelling within Foggy Bottom, Snow’s Court, witnessed some of the most prevalent changes in terms of alley development. The ADA effectively mended the initially horrid living conditions and the problems that arose with overpopulation in Snows Court. Because of their actions, Snows Court today is affiliated primarily with the middle and the upper class.
== References ==
{{reflist}}
Borchert, James. Alley Life in Washington: Family, Community, Religion, and Folklife in the City, 1850-1970. Urbana: University of Illinois, 1980. Print.
"First Lady Biography: Eleanor Roosevelt." The National First Lady Library. The National First Lady Library, n.d. Web. 26 Apr. 2013. <http://www.firstladies.org/biographies/firstladies.aspx?biography=33>.
Sherwood, Suzanne Berry. Foggy Bottom, 1800-1975: A Study in the Uses of an Urban Neighborhood. Washington: George Washington University, 1978. Print.

{{For|the novel by J. K. Rowling|The Casual Vacancy}} {{more citations needed|date=March 2018}} {{Politics}}
In [[politics]], a '''casual vacancy''' (''casual'' in the sense of "by chance") is a situation in which a seat in a deliberative assembly becomes vacant during that assembly's term. Casual vacancies may arise through the [[death in office|death]], [[resignation]] or [[disqualification (law)|disqualification]] of the sitting member, or for other reasons.
Casual vacancies have the effect of eliminating or reducing the representation for the member's constituency. Accordingly, many jurisdictions provide by law for the speedy filling of vacant seats.
Casual vacancies can also occur in non-governmental assemblies, such as [[board of directors|boards of directors]] and [[committee]]s of [[voluntary organisation]]s.
==Australia== {{main|Casual vacancies in the Australian Parliament}}
==Canada== Vacancies in the [[House of Commons of Canada]] are filled by the scheduling of a [[by-election]] in the affected district. The [[Writ of election|writ for a by-election]] must be [[dropping the writ|dropped]] no sooner than 11 days and no later than 180 days after the [[Chief Electoral Officer (Canada)|Chief Electoral Officer]] is officially notified of a vacancy via a warrant issued by the [[Speaker of the House of Commons of Canada|Speaker]]. Under the [[Canada Elections Act]], the minimum length of a campaign is 36 days between dropping the writ and election day.<ref name=hillaug>{{cite news|url=http://www.hilltimes.com/news/news/2013/08/12/journalists-vying-for-seat-in-commons-shows-politics-changing-spector/35576|title=Journalists vying for seat in Commons shows politics changing: Spector|publisher=The Hill Times|date=August 12, 2013|accessdate=August 12, 2013}}</ref> A seat can, in some cases, be vacant for even longer; prior to the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|2015 federal election]], for example, [[Stephen Harper]] had to call three by-elections in 2015. However, as the length of time the seats were vacant required that a byelection be called but the length of time remaining before the general election campaign began was too short to justify actually holding one, he scheduled the by-election dates as the date of the general election itself — a technical formality which essentially meant that a by-election was scheduled but would never actually be held. The by-elections were superseded by the general election at the dissolution of parliament on August 2, 2015 and the dropping of the federal election writ.<ref name=super>{{cite web|title=By-elections called for October 19, 2015 – What you need to know|url=http://www.elections.ca/content.aspx?section=ele&dir=2015&document=faqby2015&lang=e|website=Elections Canada|publisher=Elections Canada|accessdate=July 4, 2015}}</ref>
As the [[Senate of Canada]] is an appointed rather than elected body, vacancies in that body are simply filled with a new appointment.
By-elections are also held to fill vacancies in Canada's provincial or territorial legislatures.
==Singapore== A [[by-election]] is usually called when an incumbent [[Parliament of Singapore|MP]] vacates his or her seat in a [[Constituencies of Singapore#Single Member Constituencies|SMC]] or when all MPs vacates their seat together in a GRC.
In a recent case according to then Minister in the [[Prime Minister's Office (Singapore)|Prime Minister's Office]] [[Chan Chun Sing]], a by-election need not be called if a GRC MP resigns or is incapacitated in any way. The reason is the GRC scheme is meant to achieve two purposes: Ensure there are enough minority members in the House and ensure no political campaigning is done on issues of race and religion. These goals would not be affected if one member of the GRC left, Mr Chan added. However it did not cater for instances where the minority race MP vacates their seat hence the [[Singapore Democratic Party|SDP]] filed a suit to clarify the matter.<ref>https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/sdp-files-lawsuit-challenging-decision-not-to-call-by-election-9213508</ref> The High Court judge rejected the bid to hold a by-election and SDP withdraws the suit after a thorough explanation by the Deputy AG.<ref>https://sg.news.yahoo.com/bid-hold-election-marsiling-yew-tee-rejected-high-court-090607976.html</ref>
==New Zealand== {{As of|2008}}, the [[New Zealand House of Representatives]] has 70 seats whose members represent geographical constituencies, and a further 52 seats selected from party lists. A vacancy in any of the 70 "electorate seats" is filled through a [[by-election]]. The writ for the by-election must, in most circumstances, be issued within 21 days of the notification of the vacancy. A by-election is not required if Parliament is due to expire within six months.
By contrast, a vacancy in one of the "list seats" is filled by the next available candidate on the list submitted by the [[political party|party]] holding that seat.
==United States== The term "casual vacancy" is not commonly used in the United States. A vacancy in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] is filled by a special election. The [[United States Constitution|Constitution]] requires the executive authority (i.e. the governor) of the state concerned to issue writs of election.
The [[Seventeenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|seventeenth amendment]] provides that vacancies in the [[United States Senate|Senate]] filled by an appointment by the governor unless the legislature of the state concerned has passed a law providing some other means to fill the vacancy, such as a popular election.
